subject: Re: Running tests using an application server
msgSnippet: ... web/app ... Ideally, unit tests should be run outside of any server or container context. ... Ugh.  You shouldn t be hitting a database in your unit tests.
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Tambascio, Larry" <ltambascio@i...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> It sounds like what you need is a framework called Cactus
> (http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus). It extends JUnit to run in a
web/app
> container. It is well documented. Enjoy!
>
> -Larry
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: boothana [mailto:boothana@y...]
> Sent: Tuesday, September 09, 2003 8:53 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Running tests using an application server
>
>
> I currently use a JBoss web server, and the barracuda framework. I
> need to run my unit tests.

Ideally, unit tests should be run outside of any server or container
context.

> what I am looking at accomplishing with these unit tests is that I
> should be able to get data from the database, and use the retrieved
> data in the unit tests.

Ugh. You shouldn't be hitting a database in your unit tests. Isolate
yourself from it. Use an abstraction layer, use interfaces, mock it.

> I am able to accomplish this using JBuilder IDE

Switch IDEs if possible (IDEA, Eclipse/WSAD are better alternatives)

> but I would like to run my tests from the command line. When I use
> the junit.swingui.TestRunner class, it runs fine as long what I am
> testing is tn the current jvm, but the database operations happen,
> through JBoss and this part of my test is failing.

You're too coupled to the execution context. Factor your business
logic (the important stuff) into regular classes that can be tested in
isolation.

Someone suggested Cactus. That's excellent for intergration level
testing... not for unit level testing.

Dave
